title: The Role of Family and Friends in Shaping Your Habits
summary: We imitate the habits of three groups: the close (family and friends), the many (the tribe), and the powerful (those with status and prestige). To build better habits, join a culture where your desired behavior is normal. The shared identity of a group makes habits more attractive.
keyIdeas: We imitate the habits of those close to us, those we see often, and those we admire.
Join a culture where your desired behavior is the normal behavior.
Surround yourself with people who have the habits you want.
Shared identity makes habits more attractive and sustainable.
Your social environment shapes your habits more than you realize.
Belonging to a group creates peer pressure that reinforces habits.
The normal behavior of your tribe often overpowers the desired behavior of the individual.
examples: Join a running club if you want to become a runner.
Attend a book club to make reading a social habit.
Find a community of people who share your goals.
exercises: Identify one group or community that shares your desired habit.
List 3 people in your life whose habits you'd like to adopt.
Find one way to make your desired behavior more social.
reflections: What group could you join to make your desired habit normal?
How is your current social circle influencing your habits?
